title: Understanding the Root Mean Square Speed Formula
text: The root mean square speed (rms speed) of gas molecules is given by the formula: rms speed $$=$$ $$\sqrt{\frac{3R T}{M}}$$, where R is the gas constant, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and M is the molar mass of the gas.

title: Analyzing the Formula
text: Notice that the rms speed is inversely proportional to the square root of the molar mass (M). This means that as the molar mass increases, the rms speed decreases.

title: Effect of Molar Mass on Speed
text: If you have two gases at the same temperature, the gas with the larger molar mass will have a lower rms speed compared to the gas with a smaller molar mass.

title: Comparing Different Gases
text: Consider two gases, A and B, where gas A has a molar mass of $$4$$ $$\frac{g}{mol}$$ and gas B has a molar mass of $$16$$ $$\frac{g}{mol}$$. According to the rms speed formula, which gas will have a higher speed?

title: Final Consideration
text: Remember that the temperature is constant for both gases, so the only variable affecting the rms speed is the molar mass. Use this information to determine the correct statement about the mixture of gases.
